Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can draw a scenario that shows a material before and after heating or cooling, indicating whether the change is reversible.
The student can illustrate a melting ice cube turning into water to show a reversible change, and then show water freezing back to ice.
The student can depict a raw egg being heated, becoming a cooked egg, highlighting the irreversible nature of the change.
The student can include labels or descriptions that explain the characteristics of materials before and after heating or cooling.
The student can represent the concept of reversible changes by demonstrating how some materials can return to their original state after being altered.
The student can indicate the concept of irreversible changes by showing how some materials do not return to their original state after being heated or cooled.
